resource.chars:
foot note p. 38
<s>Recd. 27 April 1865<\s>
[When my remarks on the equatorial current between Cape Rogue 
and the West Indian islands were written I was not aware if [of?]
the very interesting observations, which General Sabine 
made in 1822 on the influence of the water of the Amazon 
river on that of the Equatorial current. I shall now insert 
them here their bearing being in the same way as my 
deficient observations.
In 5[degrees] <s>0<\s>8’ N. lat and 50[degrees] 28’ W. long a distinct line of separation 
was observed between the pure blue water of the ocean, and the 
disco<s>u<\s>loured water mixed with that from the Amazon river
the mouth of which was about 300 miles distant. The blue water 
had a sp. gr. of 1,0262, which acording to my calculation (pag. 37) is = 33,672 p.m. salt 
while the water on the other side of the line of separation was 1,0204 = 26,345 p.m. salt 
further on under the influence of the river it was 1,0185 = 23,800 p.m. salt.
But the river water kept on the surface and in a depth of 126 feet 
the sp. gr. was was 1,0262 (= 33,672 p.m. salt)
In 7[degrees] <s>0<\s>1’ N. lat and 52[degrees] 38’,5 W. long the sp. gr. was 1,0245 = 31,905 p.m. salt 
and in 120 feet depth again 1,0262 sp. gr.
In 7[degrees] <s>05<\s> lat and 53[degrees] 38’,5 W. long the sp. gr. was 1,0245 = 31,905 p.m. salt
In the Gulf of Paria off the mouth of the Orinoco the sp.
gr. was 1,0204 = 26,345 p.m. salt and in crossing one of the branches 
of the river itself the sp. gr. was found to be only 1,0064 =  8,234 p.m. sa[lt]
see, An Account of experiments to determine the figure of the Earth 
by Edw. Sabine. London 1825”. - G.7., April, 1855.]
